content: The 9/11 Commission found that al Qaeda terrorists exploited weaknesses in aviation security, including a focus on potential bombers rather than hijackers, lax checkpoint screening, lack of in-flight security measures, industry compliance with hijackers, and a failure of imagination among policymakers. The 9/11 Commission identified a failure of imagination among senior policymakers and agencies responsible for intelligence, national defense, and aviation security. Before September 11, 2001, there were no specific actions taken to defend against the possibility of suicide hijackings, which were greatly underestimated. Congressional oversight of aviation security was lacking, with a focus on airport congestion and passenger service rather than potential threats. After the 9/11 attacks, Congress quickly passed the Aviation and Transportation Security Act (ATSA) to address weaknesses in aviation security. ATSA established the Transportation Security Administration, mandated federal security screeners at airports, required explosive detection screening for checked bags, deployed air marshals on high-risk flights, and reinforced cockpit doors. Congressional oversight had previously focused on airport congestion and passenger service rather than terrorism threats.
